FEDERATION OF MALAYSIA


2.32 p.m.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Sir, I rise to move the motion standing in my name*.
* The motion reads as follows:-

    That, in pursuance of this national objective of a united Malayan nation, enlarged and strengthened by the addition of our brothers in the Borneo territories, this House declares its support in principle for the plan proposed by the Prime Minister of the Federation of Malaya, Tunku Abdul Rahman Putra Al-Haj, and agreed to in principle in the Federation Parliament on 18th October, 1961, for the establishment of the Federation of Malaysia, comprising the eleven States of the present Federation, the States of Singapore and Brunei, and the territories of Sarawak and North Borneo.


    This motion was first tabled in the House for debate in November last year, to be taken together with two other motions; the first supporting merger in principle, and the second as accepting the heads of agreement published in Cmd. Paper 33 of 1961, as a working basis for a merger between Singapore and the Federation of Malaya. As a result of the long debate on the question of merger, it is not possible to take a vote on ths motion before the second meeting of the Malaysia Solidarity Consultative Committee which was held in Kuching from the 18th to the 20th of December last year. This was a meeting intended to bring together all those members of the legislative chambers of the live territories who supported Malaysia in principle and wanted to help the Solidarity Committee quicken its realisation.

    However, belated though this motion may be, it is not without its value, for it is as well from time to time to have all

Column: 582

Members of the Assembly, state for the record, whether they are, in principle, for or against Malaysia, or whether they are, for various reasons, unable to make a stand and, therefore, abstaining from the vote, either openly in this Chamber, or surreptitiously by absenting themselves.

    However, in moving this motion, I am assured by two facts. Firstly, that members of the Barisan Sosialis have always claimed to support, in principle, both merger and Malaysia and had asked for their representative to attend the Solidarity Committee meetings as a member of the Singapore delegation. We had gladly agreed to the Member for Thomson as their representative and he was present at both meetings of the Solidarity Committee meeting in Kuching last December and in Kuala Lumpur a fortnight ago. Since only those who support Malaysia in principle were invited to attend and the Barisan Sosialis had asked to attend, logically we can assume that they support Malaysia in principle. Furthermore, when the Member for Thomson was pressed to state his stand at the meeting in Kuching, he stated categorically, off the cuff, that he fully supported Malaysia, but he added that he had to ensure that the people of the Borneo territories were fully looked after - as if the people of the Borneo territories could not look after themselves. The other fact which has given me great encouragement was the resolution on West Irian, on which, Sir, there was studious effort made to differentiate West Irian from Malaysia.

    Sir, taking a stand on any issue, be it West Irian or Malaysia, presents no difficulty to political Parties with an open and straightforward stand like the P.A.P. But Parties like the Barisan who do not stand for what they claim to

Column: 583

stand for may find themselves in considerable difficulty if they start supporting things they do not really support. I do not know whether these things were carefully thought out and all the implications made as between a stand on West Irian and a stand on Malaysia. I would have thought that here indeed was the height of contradiction. In supporting the liberation of West Irian as the P.A.P. did, we were supporting the liberation of an integral part of a European empire in South-East Asia, which has still to be freed in order to complete the independence of what were formerly the territories of the Dutch Empire in South-East Asia. And so Afro-Asian nationalists support the right of succession of the Indonesian Republic to West Irian, for Dutch New Guinea was an integral part of the Netherlands East Indies. The Dutch Empire once spread over the 3,000-odd islands now constituting the Republic of Indonesia, and so the Indonesians right y dismiss all Dutch talk of self-determination for a few hundred thousand papuans in Dutch New Guinea as imperialistic nonsense designed to delay matters.

    So, in the same way, we support the rights of the people of Singapore and the three Borneo territories to be liberated from the British and to join together with the Federation of Malaya to constitute the Federation of Malaysia consisting of all the territories which once formed the British Empire in South-East Asia.

    Sir, I am happy that the Barisan Sosialis has sided with the Indonesians in condemning the imperialistic powers who support the Dutch in putting forward this excuse of self-determination for the Papuans. West Irian is part of Indonesia, and to Indonesia it must return. But I am disappointed, however, that the same militant anti-colonial spirit vanishes completely when they are asked to take a stand on Malaysia. Here is a concrete issue on our own doorstep on which they can express their anti-colonial fervour to fight colonialism without any danger of being sent, ill-equipped, to land on some hostile shores, or probably be sunk before they are

Column: 584

landed. Nobody is asking them to volunteer to risk their life and limb. All we are asking them to do is to take a stand to liberate the three Borneo territories and Singapore to form an independent sovereign nation together with the Federation of Malaya.

    Sir, from what the Member for Thomson has said for the Barisan Sosialis in Kuching, I gather that having said that he supported Malaysia in principle, he was then interested in taking the Dutch colonial line of gradual self-determination for each individual divided territory. This very same line they condemned when taken by the Dutch on West Irian, but quite shamelessly adopted by them when it suits their Communist interests to oppose Malaysia. So the fierce fighters of the Barisan Sosialis and their Communist friends and supporters were prepared to find women to fight for the liberation of West Irian. Sir, the Chairman of the Barisan Sosialis was somewhat apologetic yesterday when he explained that he could not find these three women on their records. Even more shameless, Sir, if they had to sacrifice three of their women members, at least, I would have respected them for it. But to find three innocent women, who were not even members of the Barisan Sosialis, and ask them to go out and talk the Barisan Sosialis propaganda line was a heartless and cold-blooded act akin to murder. Sir, the strange thing about the Barisan Sosialis is that they always believe in sending women and children first to the front line.

    An hon. Member: The Work Brigade!

    The Prime Minister: The Work Brigade and the schools - a very strange characteristic of the fierce freedom fighters. Now, they are actively trying to create difficulty and confusion over Malaysia. They know that with Malaysia there will be a strengthening of nationalist anti-colonial forces, and their Communist anti-colonial forces will be isolated and confined. But that is their problem; a problem that faces those who expound the cause of democracy when

Column: 585

they do not believe in it; expound non-Communism when, in fact, they are Communists; and Socialism when, in fact, they mean Communism.

    Sir, 1962 is likely to be a memorable year in the annals of South-East Asia for two issues, Malaysia and West Irian. I am looking forward during this debate to see what they are going to say and how they are going to vote, or perhaps, whether they are going to vote at all. All good and honest democrats always stand up to be counted. It is only the Communists in democrat clothing who always find it embarrassing when the doctor comes around to remove their democratic clothing for a closer examination.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

2.44 p.m.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh (Queenstown): Mr Speaker, Sir, it is a pity the Prime Minister again ridicules the volunteers after what I had said last evening. Surely he should pay some respect, if not to the volunteers, at least, to the Indonesian people themselves. He referred again to self-determination. I was very careful to explain last evening to the house, that words like "merger" and "self-determination" have been completely twisted out of shape by the P.A.P. Merger to the P.A.P. means the enslavement of Singapore; merger to other people means equality, justice and democracy. Everybody in this House excepting the P.A.P. says that it is not merger.

    Similarly self-determination. In our explanation, we have to explain to people who are so dense as not to understand that self-determination in the case of West Irian was meant to be a move for sponsoring a puppet regime for the imperialists. In our case, self-determination would give us an opportunity to decide our own fate and would give us the opportunity to fight for the unity of the people. However, Sir, the Prime

Column: 586

Minister in moving this motion is obviously trying to repeat what the Minister for Labour did when he moved the motion calling for support on the principle of merger. It does seem to be a favourite trick of the P.A.P. to talk of wonderful principles of unity, prosperity and what-not and then to smuggle in constitutional changes that will, in effect, frustrate the people's hopes and aspirations under the cloak of these very same principles. In the case of Malaysia, through the Malaysia Solidarity Consultative Committee and other meetings, the P.A.P. would like us and like everybody to get excited over this principle of Malaysia. They want everybody to start shouting, "We support Malaysia." And then when everybody is in an elated mood, the P.A.P. hope to twist this euphoria to mean support for a specific set o proposals which will not be to the best interests of the people but which will, on the contrary, go to consolidate reactionary rule in this region.

    Sir, the Prime Minister always likes to give us glowing pictures of El Dorados in his various Press interviews, in his various radio forums. But the Malaysia that is being unfolded before our eyes is not a Malaysia that is going to bring equality, freedom, democracy and social justice to the peoples of Singapore, Sabah, Brunei and Sarawak. On the contrary, it is going to spread reaction, injustice, inequality and disunity among these peoples. Sir, we are not going to fall into the trap of concentrating on the principle and forgetting about the details - equally important details - that go to give form, substance and meaning to this principle. Today, we are dealing with people whose first considerations are not the realisation of the hopes and aspirations of the people. We are dealing with desperate and unscrupulous politicians whose first considerations are how to keep themselves in office. And because of that, we have to be very careful.

    Sir, what is this Malaysia scheme that they have been talking so much about? As far as the people of Singapore are concerned, this Malaysia scheme merely means the P.A.P. White Paper Merger

Column: 587

proposals and nothing else - just the P.A.P. White Paper merger proposals. The Federation Government have made it quite clear that Singapore is not going to be accepted and be truly merged with the Federation. Singapore is going to be only a so-called partner with separate citizenship and with no proportional representation. That is, Malaysia's merger and the P.A.P.'s merger are one and the same thing. It is a package-deal. The Tunku has said so many times, "If there is no Malaysia, there is no merger with Singapore." And as we have rejected the White Paper proposals, we therefore similarly reject this motion.

    Sir, as I have said, the present Malaysia scheme merely serves to consolidate reactionary rule over the entire region. It is regrettable indeed that the P.A.P. leaders who call themselves Socialists should so eagerly support a scheme which strengthens the forces of reaction and colonialism and which is being strongly opposed by Socialist Parties in the whole region.

    Sir, let it be made quite clear. We do not object to the concept of Malaysia as a concept. The idea of a large political unit in the Malaysian region is not new. It was originally put forth by progressive leaders in Malaya and Indonesia after World War II - and even before that, I understand. The primary object behind the original idea of Malaysia was to advance the interests of the peoples of the region. It was to unite the peoples in their struggle to eradicate all traces of imperialist domination and to bring about political freedom, unity and stability to the entire region so that the peoples can benefit from a planned socialist development of the rich material resources. Sir, we in the Barisan Sosialis fully subscribe to the concept of peoples in more and more countries coming together for mutual interests and mutual benefits. We will always support any move that will bring about a larger union of countries and peoples and that will help a planned socialist economic development for benefit of all the people. As socialists, we believe that peoples from different lands can live happily together, not in competition, but

Column: 588

in co-operation. Socialists do not see any basic antagonism between the interests of the peoples from different countries, and we are confident that the day will come when the whole human race on earth will live happily together as one happy family.

    Sir, we therefore welcome any move that will genuinely bring about closer relationship between the peoples of the Federation of Malaya, the three Borneo territories and Singapore. But any such move must be based on a genuine desire to bring about greater benefits to the peoples of this region. In other words, it must be motivated only by a sincere desire to advance the interests of the peoples of these territories and should certainly not be for the benefit of imperialists and reactionary forces in this region. If the concept of Malaysia is going to bring about happiness to the people, then the only way is to ensure that the peoples of this region can decide their own future. Let true democracy be practised. Sir, I shall deal with this aspect in more detail later.

    First, let us ask, how do the British come in? Sir, you will realise that colonialism is on the retreat all over the world. We have seen the upsurge of the Afro-Asian spirit in the struggle for greater freedom and greater democratic rights. The French have been driven out of Indo-China. The Portuguese have just been evicted from Goa. And we see the remnants of colonialism about to be liquidated in West Irian. But what has happened in Singapore and in the Borneo territories? Sir, the British are experienced colonialists. They know their days are numbered as far as this region is concerned. They know they will have to return the power to the people soon. The British are, therefore, faced with two alternatives: either to continue direct colonial rule of these territories in the face of increasing popular opposition, in which case they know that they may eventually lose everything; or to rule indirectly by transferring political power to the pro-Western politicians while continuing to maintain an effective economic and

Column: 589

military control over these territories. Sir, these political concessions, however, are more apparent than real as the economic and military control will remain the same as before. Such indirect rule has an advantage over direct and overt colonial rule in that it can confuse certain sections of our people into believing that the colonial master is no more present. But it is not difficult to see that, after all, it will only be just colonialism in disguise and, in fact, it will help to prolong colonial domination. It will also enable the colonial power to boast that it has granted "independence" to its colonies. This is important, Sir, in view of the fact that the United Nations have recently passed a resolution calling for an immediate end to colonialism. Sir, Britain favours or is in favour of Malaysia, and in view of what I have said, do we still need to ask why Britain is enthusiastic about Malaysia? From our viewpoint, there are two reasons, Sir. Firstly, from the long term point of view, this plan will provide the British with a safe means of retreat when the time comes for them to give up direct colonial rule. It will allow the British to continue their economic and military domination of this region by indirect control through their influence over pro-Western local leaders. The present Federation Government appears to be a safe bet for the British, as it has been made very clear that it does not intend to harm British economic interests in this region.

    Secondly, the British hope that this plan will help to distract the attention of our peoples from the existence of a colonial power by getting us all too preoccupied with the problems of merger, thus putting a brake on our anti-colonial movement. We will be told that the problem before us is not one of getting rid of the British but one of merging among ourselves. And, of course, this problem will be made more difficult by constant harping on the minor difference existing amongst our peoples. Our racial and religious differences will be distorted and emphasised,

Column: 590

and our different approaches, to education, for example, will be magnified and made an excuse for obstructing a genuine reunification.

    Sir, we have seen all these mischievous political games in Singapore before, and evidently they are going to be repeated in the Borneo territories. The British hope that the energies of the people in Borneo will be similarly dissipated in fighting amongst themselves and with the Federation Government, so that the existence of the colonial power will be temporarily forgotten by them. We see clearly why this Malaysia plan fits into the British scheme of things. It helps to divert the people's attention from fighting against the colonial power to fighting among themselves. And it is a move to protect British economic interests.

    Sir, I do not need to labour on this point any further except to say, in passing, that Malaysia or no Malaysia, we are willy-nilly drawn into a cold war. We already know that as regards the British bases in Singapore, Britain will continue to use them as a matter of right after Malaysia.

    The Prime Minister: Sandra Woodhull agreed to all this.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Britain will only consult the proposed Malaysia Government as a matter of courtesy. Therefore, there is no change regarding the bases, Malaysia or no Malaysia. For example, we learn that rocket launching sites are already being placed around Singapore and V-bombers armed with nuclear weapons are equipped and on the ready. This means that we shall be directly drawn into the cold war between the two power blocs.

    The Prime Minister: You can go to Borneo.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Sir, if our country is going to be used as a nuclear base in the event of a major world war, then the peoples of the whole region will be placed right at the front line. This is not what we want. We want peace and neutrality. We want to be

Column: 591

with the non-allied countries of Afro-Asia. The Malaysia that we want is a Malaysia that must not be a pawn of big power politics.

    It is significant to note, Sir, that the Permanent Secretariat of the Afro-Asian People's Solidarity Organisation had issued a statement in Cairo on 4th December, 1961, strongly condemning the British plot to rig up a Federation of Malaysia in South-East Asia. The statement said that the purpose of the British in this Malaysia plan is to suppress the national liberation movement of South-East Asia. It calls on the people of Asia and Africa to be vigilant against colonial manoeuvres and to take all necessary steps to frustrate the British plot.

    Sir, the Western powers are also evidently trying to use the Malaysia scheme to bring about the political isolation of our peoples in Singapore and the Borneo territories from the mainstream of Afro-Asia, which is vigorously led in this part of the world by Indonesia. The spirit of Afro-Asia is the spirit of oppressed peoples all over the world. It is the spirit that is crying for freedom, equality and justice. It is the spirit of young nations throughout the world. It is the spirit of young nations refusing to be drawn into the cold war conflict, of young nations trying to stand on their own feet after centuries of colonial domination, and of nations refusing to be used as pawns in big power politics. The peoples of Singapore and the Borneo territories are largely inspired by the spirit of Afro-Asia. It is this desire to remain neutral and to be free that had led the people of Singapore to elect at the last general elections a Party which then professed to be non-Communist and anti-colonial, but which has since deviated and abandoned both these basic platforms, and now become obsessed with the negative philosophy of anti-Communism.

    Sir, our wanting to rally under the banner of Afro-Asia, of course, will not be to the interests of the colonial powers, because Afro-Asia means neutrality between the two power blocs and, understandably, the British would

Column: 592

like to use the Malaysia scheme to forestall the growing influence of the Afro-Asian spirit amongst the peoples of Singapore and the Borneo territories, and to help keep our peoples under the influence and domination of the Western capitalist world so that we can continue to be exploited and subjugated and become mere pawns in big power politics.

    Sir, our Prime Minister had on previous occasions referred to Brunei as a possible Kuwait if it did not merge with Malaya. He said that Kuwait had trouble immediately it was given independence. This country has a population of a few hundred thousand people while Brunei has a population of only, say, about 80,000 people. He said that Brunei too is oil-rich and sudden independence might bring new problems. From this, Sir, it is clear that our Prime Minister is even prepared to fit himself into Western designs by souring up relations between the people of the Borneo territories and the people of Indonesia. Let us ask: is it not to imply that if the people of Brunei did not join the proposed Malaysia and so become dominated by the Federation Government; their territory would instead be conquered by Indonesia? That is the implication, Sir. But the Indonesian Government has already made it clear that it has no claim on the Borneo territories now under British rule. So why such an analogy? Is it not a very mischievous thing?

    Sir, the P.A.P. used to talk about fostering better relationships with the Indonesian people. But now, having lost the support of the people, the P.A.P. leadership is even prepared to help the Western powers against Indonesia. I do not believe -

    The Prime Minister: On a point of clarification, Sir.

    Mr Speaker: If the Member will give way.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: I do not believe, for one moment, Sir, that the Indonesian people, having tasted oppression themselves, would want to force upon the people of Brunei a political system

Column: 593

which the people of Brunei themselves do not want. I am sure that Indonesia, as a leader of Afro-Asia in this region, would want to see the people of Brunei -

    The Prime Minister: What about India?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: - as free and as equal as they are themselves. It is, therefore, extremely mischievous on the part of our Prime Minister, if he knew what he was doing, to try to stir up suspicion and ill-feelings between the people of Brunei and their neighbours and friends, the Indonesian people.

    Now, how does Malaysia fit in with the present Right-wing Government of the Federation? Judging from the various statements from the Federation Government and especially from the speech delivered by the Tunku at the Federal Parliament debate on Malaysia, it is evident that the Federation Government is more keen to take in the Borneo territories than to take in Singapore itself. In fact, the Tunku has repeatedly said that he will take in Singapore only if the three Borneo territories come in at the same time.

    So let us first examine why the Federation Government is more keen to take in the Borneo territories than Singapore. The Federation Government has claimed that it has now changed its previous anti-merger stand and is now prepared to have some sort of merger with Singapore. As everybody knows, aid incidentally, Sir - but I had better leave it alone -

    The Prime Minister: You have not got clearance from your Committee.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: I wanted to say, Sir, that when the Federation Government was openly anti-merger, the P.A.P. never dared to call the Federation Government anti-nationalist or pro-Communist. That is what I wanted to say, but I thought that that did not fit in and so -

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): You have said it already.

Column: 594



    Dr Lee Siew Choh: But the Federation Government still has a pathological fear of the Chinese population in Singapore. It sees in the addition of large numbers of Chinese from Singapore into the Federation on a genuine merger a threat against the Federation Government. That is why the Federation Government and the P.A.P. have devised a constitutional arrangement whereby the political influence of Singapore citizens will be kept to a minimum, and in which we are denied equal citizenship and the right of proportional representation. Faced with what it considers to be a problem of having to counterbalance the large numbers of Chinese in Singapore, the Federation Government sees in the addition of large numbers of non-Chinese in the Borneo territories a welcome solution to its communal fears and prejudices. But we have heard the Prime Minister telling us over Radio P.A.P. that with Malaysia, by the addition of the Borneo territories, the Communist threat would be diluted.

    The Prime Minister: That is right.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: But more to the point is that with the addition of the Borneo territories the Malays, together with the indigenous population of the Borneo territories, would outnumber the Chinese. This is what will really allay the prejudices and fears of those politicians who, very unfortunately, analyse political situations only from a communal angle. Sir, we have known of this Malaysia plan of the Prime Minister of Singapore for quite some time. Long ago he had talked of Malaysia as being more acceptable to the Federation Government than just a merger between Singapore and the Federation, because the Malays would then form the predominant part of the population. It is extremely regrettable that the Prime Minister who called himself a socialist should try to play on the communal fears and prejudices of the people. Sir, the Malaysia plan appeals to the Federation Government perhaps also because of, if I may say so, the rich oil resources of Brunei. The yearly

Column: 595

revenue of Brunei is about $130 million, whereas its annual expenditure, so far as we know, is only about $30 million. This is an annual surplus of about $100 million which will, of course, help the Federation Treasury after Malaysia. So I wonder if this is the real attraction of the Borneo territories for the Federation Government. In their eagerness to bring the Borneo territories under Federation rule, the Federation Government and the P.A.P. are trying to rush the people of the Borneo territories into making a quick decision. Thus we see attempts to convert the Malaysia Solidarity Consultative Committee from a purely consultative body into semblance of a decision-making body. Sir, we do not wish to interfere with the affairs of the people of the Borneo territories -

    The Prime Minister: Quite right.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: - because we believe that the people there are fully capable of deciding their own future. And we regret there has been no genuine attempt so far to consult the views of the people of the Borneo territories on this Malaysia plan. The proposed Commission of Inquiry to assess the views of the Borneo people, like all official commissions, will be just an eye-wash. Already there is a lot of quarrelling over the choice of the Chairman. The Tunku has said many illuminating things on the true purpose of this Commission. Let me quote him in the Straits Times, Sir, of 6th December, 1961, on page 1, column 8. This is a whole paragraph:

    `"If you appoint the wrong type of Commission and get certain recommendations which you find it is not possible to accept, then the whole question of Malaysia will collapse," said the Tunku.'

Then there is another passage. It is on page 20 of the same day, column 8, and it says:

    `The British public know they have very honest and real friends. We need the right Commission to recommend the right things to accelerate this merger.'

The right Commission to recommend the right things for our Prime Minister so that he may still be in office. It is quite clear from this very frank statement by the Tunku himself that the real

Column: 596

purpose of the Commission is that it must, under all circumstances, produce quickly a very favourable report for his Malaysia proposals. It is clear too that the Commission is not intended to be an unbiased body for the proper assessment of the views of the people of the Borneo territories. It is meant to be -

    The Prime Minister: You expect to be made Chairman of the Commission?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: - a rubber stamp, Sir, so as to enable the Federation Government to declare officially that the Borneo people have been consulted and that they favour the Tunku's Malaysia plan. How nice!

    The Prime Minister: You pray the Commission to come over!

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Sir, this is, to say the very least, not a very democratic way of consulting the people of the Borneo territories. We know that the peoples of the three Borneo territories have a genuine apprehension about this whole Malaysia scheme. All this talk about the present Malaysia proposals bringing economic benefits to the Borneo territories sounds very hollow indeed, Sir, when we remember that there is not only unemployment in the Federation itself but also that the Federation Government has to borrow money from Brunei to ease its own economic difficulties.

    It has been suggested that this Malaysia scheme is going to bring freedom and independence to the peoples of Sabah, Brunei, Sarawak and Singapore. But, Sir, is this really going to be so?
